intro: Ichnanthus riedelii, commonly known as the Riedel's ghostflower, is a rare and enigmatic plant native to the high-altitude regions of southern Africa. It is a member of the Iridaceae family, characterized by its unique floral structure and adaptations to harsh environmental conditions. The plant produces striking, pale blue or white flowers that bloom in late summer, often in rocky or gravelly habitats. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it thrives in well-drained soils with ample sunlight. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, Ichnanthus riedelii is considered a vulnerable species.
